@ TimesRGud @ bornonjuly4 @ brettking long discussion. But unless you run a full bitcoin node you might as well be using any other design.
@ stevegraham @ mikekelly85 spot on. It's a new set of trade offs. But a trade off that works for some business cases.
@ TimesRGud @ brettking @ bornonjuly4 but what is the purpose? If it's just doing something better than it was done before...
@ brettking @ bornonjuly4 I would argue yes. They chain blocks of meta data.
@ mikekelly85 but those have massive inefficiencies in reconciliation OR risk creating the world's most powerful entity (systemic risk)
@ mikekelly85 and data integrity (the computer science challenge of our age)
@ mikekelly85 with multi administrators / proof of provenance over the data?
@ kathleenbreit @ ArthurB I like the auditor and traffic cop all rolled into one.
@ kathleenbreit @ ArthurB it needs a term. That's as good as any I've heard for it.
@ mikekelly85 creates a sort of tracking / audit that becomes very handy for regulators, governments, kyc, AML etc
@ mikekelly85 true. It's just an elegant way to manage signing in a multi administrator environment.
@ mikekelly85 then the banks could securely transfer the ISA detail with something like IPFS
@ mikekelly85 if you want to move your ISA to another bank, you'd change the references on the blockchain with multi sig.
@ mikekelly85 think about a global ISA registry. Ownership and signatures on a blockchain. Data in a container at bank
@ mikekelly85 the data may stay where it always lived but the references move.
@ mikekelly85 a design choice. You may want many administrators, you may also want many physical data centres but it doesn't *have* to
This may not seem sexy. But most highly profitable commercial software isn't.
If anything the # blockchain component manages referencing, permissions and reconciliation across many administrators.
Most applications of # blockchain I'm seeing close to commercialisation don't replicate and store all of the data in all of the nodes.
